searchDocs.title: Lab 1 - Creating Your VM in Azure
Purpose / Objectives of Lab 1​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Lab 1 - Creating Your VM in Azure
searchDocs.content: In this lab, you will login to Microsoft Azure for the first time, navigate your way to DevTest Labs, and create your Linux virtual machine.  The main purpose of this lab is to:  Create your Linux virtual machine environment using a pre-built imageRemotely connect to your new Linux environmentLearn basic management of VMs from the Azure web interface.  This VM will be used extensively throughout the rest of this course.  While you are working through this lab, it is highly recommended that you write down general notes and commands to help you remember how to do this lab.  If you encounter technical issues, please contact your professor via e-mail or in your section's Microsoft Teams group.

searchDocs.title: Minimum Requirements​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Lab 1 - Creating Your VM in Azure
searchDocs.content: Before beginning, you must have:  Attended the Week 1 lectures (or watched the posted recording).Your Seneca login credentials.A computer with an Internet connection. (Windows/macOS/Linux)A mobile device (phone/tablet) to setup 2FA (two-factor authentication).

searchDocs.title: Investigation 1: Connecting to Your Azure Account​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Lab 1 - Creating Your VM in Azure
searchDocs.content: In this investigation, you'll log in to your Seneca-provided Azure account and ensure you have access to our DevTest Labs digital classroom

searchDocs.title: Part 1: Logging In For The First Time​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Lab 1 - Creating Your VM in Azure
searchDocs.content: Follow the link to our DevTest Lab in Azure found on Blackboard.Enter your Seneca credentials. (Same username and password you use for your e-mail)You'll next be asked to set up two-factor authentication. Do not bypass this step!Once you've set that up, verify it by logging out and logging back in again.Conduct a small celebration (pat on the back, a quick jig, perhaps a fist pump) and move on to Investigation 2.

searchDocs.title: Part 2: Logging In Afterwards​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Lab 1 - Creating Your VM in Azure
searchDocs.content: Logging in after initial setup is quite easy.  Navigate to the Azure portal: https://portal.azure.comUse your Seneca credentials.Complete 2FA authentication.Our classroom DevTest Lab will be in your recent list, or you can use the search bar to bring up DevTest Labs by looking for UNX510. (DO NOT search for Virtual Machines in the search bar. You will find yourself in the wrong area and things will not work.)

searchDocs.title: Investigation 2: Managing a CentOS Linux VM in Azure​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Lab 1 - Creating Your VM in Azure
searchDocs.content: In this investigation, you'll create, configure, and manage a Linux CentOS Minimal Virtual Machine using Microsoft Azure and a pre-built image.  This means no tedious and time-consuming Linux installation!  This is a command line only OS, so you'll be using SSH to remotely connect to the VM and issue basic commands.

searchDocs.title: Part 1: Creating A Linux VM From An Image​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Lab 1 - Creating Your VM in Azure
searchDocs.content: To create your Linux Virtual machine, perform the following steps:  Navigate to DevTest Labs > UNX510 > My virtual machinesClick the + Add button.Wait for the Choose a base listing to populate. This may take a few moments.Select the item titled CentOS-based 7.9. Be careful here! There are many other options.A new blade, Create lab resource appears.In the Virtual machine name field, type: yourSenecaUsername-lnx (you only have 15 characters, you may need to abbreviate)Username: yourSenecaUsernameUse a saved secret: UncheckedPassword: Your choice, but use the same for all VMs and resources in this course.Save as default password: Checked.Virtual machine size: Standard_B1sOS disk type: Standard HDDLeave the remaining options as they are.Click on the Create button at the bottom of the screen.You are now back in the My virtual machines blade while Azure creates your personal virtual machine. This may take a few minutes.When it finishes, you should see a Your deployment is complete. message near the top of the page. Congratulations!Click on the Go to resource button at the bottom left of the page.Take a full desktop screenshot of the results in the above step and add it as an attachment to this question.Move on to the next section of the lab.  When deployment is complete, click on the new VM in My virtual machines to verify its status and find the VM's address. Write this address down.

searchDocs.title: Part 2: Accessing Your CentOS VM Remotely Using SSH​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Lab 1 - Creating Your VM in Azure
searchDocs.content: Requirements: An SSH Client  Windows: Use the built-in Command Prompt or PowerShell.macOS/Linux: Use the built-in Terminal application.  We will be accessing our new Linux VM remotely using SSH.  In the Overview tab for the Virtual Machine created in Part 1, look forIP address or FQDN entry. This is the address you will use to connect in this section. Write it down (Hover over the URL, and you'll see a Copy to clipboard icon).NAT protocol / Port to connect entry. This is the port you'll use to connect in this section. Write it down. (Don't use the Copy to clipboard icon, as all you want is the port number, i.e. 30070 for example.)On Windows Using Command Prompt, or macOS/Linux Using Terminal: From the command line, enter the following (using your address from the Overview tab): ssh -p portnumber yourSenecaUsername@addressWhen prompted for a password, use the one you gave when you created the VM. (You won't see anything as you type here; that's normal.)If login is successful, you should see a prompt like this:  [cjohnson30@cjohnson30-lnx ~]$      To prove you've completed this section, run the following command: hostnamectlTake a full desktop screenshot of the results in the above step and add it as an attachment to this question.To quit your remote SSH session, type: exitDo not skip Part 3 at this stage! Otherwise, you'll be bleeding funds by leaving the VM running.

searchDocs.title: Part 3: Fully Stopping Your Windows Virtual Machine​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Lab 1 - Creating Your VM in Azure
searchDocs.content: This section is fairly simple. The one thing to never forget: Ensure your VM's status is set to Stopped (Deallocated).  In the Overview blade of your CentOS Linux VM, click on the Stop button.A notification will appear in the top right of your browser window, confirming your action.Don't worry about going into the Linx OS and shutting down first. Azure sends a signal to the VM to shut down safely.If your VM status says stopped, but does not include the (Deallocated) text, then resources are still being held by the VM and we're still being charged. The stop button will still be available, so click it.Take a full desktop screenshot of the results in the above step and add it as an attachment to this question.  Figure 2. Example of Deallocated view in Azure

searchDocs.title: Investigation 4: Managing Your VM Directly Through Azure's UI​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Lab 1 - Creating Your VM in Azure
searchDocs.content: In this quick investigation, we'll walk through how to directly manage virtual machines from the Azure Dashboard interface on a basic level. This is useful for starting up VMs, shutting them down when unresponsive, and deleting them when you're finished.  (Warning: Do not delete the VM created in this lab!)  IMPORTANT - After creating your VM for the first time, you must log out and log back in to Azure. When you first create a VM in DevTest Labs (DTL) and it's in a fully running state, you need to log out and log back into the Azure Portal for permissions to be added properly to your account. If you don't, you'll get Permission denied warnings from Azure if you try to do this investigation.

searchDocs.title: Part 1: Powering On A Virtual Machine​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Lab 1 - Creating Your VM in Azure
searchDocs.content: From the DevTest Labs blade:  Click on the My virtual machines menu bar item.Click on the virtual machine you'd like to manage to move to its Overview blade.Click the Start menu button near the top.

searchDocs.title: Part 2: Powering Off A Virtual Machine​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Lab 1 - Creating Your VM in Azure
searchDocs.content: From the DevTest Labs blade:  Click on the My virtual machines menu bar item.Click on the virtual machine you'd like to manage to move to its Overview blade.Click the Stop menu button near the top.  Remember the difference between the status Stopped and Stopped (deallocated)!

searchDocs.title: Part 3: Restarting A Virtual Machine​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Lab 1 - Creating Your VM in Azure
searchDocs.content: There are two methods to restarting a VM. Either within the OS, or through the Azure Dashboard.  From inside the Linux OS:  Run the following:  sudo reboot   You will then be disconnected from your remote session. Wait a few minutes while the VM restarts, and reconnect.  From Azure Dashboard:  Click on the Restart button from the VM's Overview blade.Wait until the VM's status has changed to Running before logging back in.

searchDocs.title: Part 4: Deleting A Virtual Machine​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Lab 1 - Creating Your VM in Azure
searchDocs.content: Deleting a Virtual Machine is useful when you no longer need it long-term, or if there's a catastrophic issue with the OS inside. Be careful! Any saved data inside the VM will be deleted as well!  Navigate to the VM's Overview blade.If the VM status isn't Stopped (Deallocated), stop the VM. Wait until its status updates.Click on the Delete button at the top of the blade.

searchDocs.title: Part 5: A Note About Resource Usage​
searchDocs.pageTitle: Lab 1 - Creating Your VM in Azure
searchDocs.content: As mentioned during our lecture and throughout this lab, using resources responsibly is incredibly important. We pay for what we use. While we have a fail-safe in place to stop all VMs at 2:00am EST daily, don't rely on it!  Fully stop your VM when you're not using them.  Your total allowed resource allocation has been restricted for this course. This means you can only have one VM in existence at a time. If you have one already, you won't be able to add another until you delete one.
